Lesson 3: Avoiding Procrastination

We’ve established the importance of setting goals and the need to build in time for interruptions because they’re bound to happen and to distract you from what you’re working so hard to achieve!

However, we know that sometimes we can make goals and lists, but never get to some of the key items on the list.

Procrastination can get in the way of success.

But don’t worry! Here are some steps you can take to get around procrastination.

Step 1: Figure Out if You Are Procrastinating

Instructions: Read through the following questions. Using the dropdowns select Yes or No for each question. Select the Submit Answers button to submit your answers.

Are you:


Thank you for submitting your response! If you answered yes to any of these questions you are not alone. Many people need extra support to avoid procrastinating and getting through the tasks they need to complete.

Step 2: Work Out Why You Are Procrastinating

WHY you are procrastinating can depend on both you and the task. Understanding which of the two it is can help you identify how you will overcome your procrastination.

Instructions: Select each dropdown below to learn more about why you may procrastinate.

  • Unpleasant Tasks

    One obvious reason is that people tend to avoid unpleasant tasks. Brian Tracy calls this “the frog” in his book Eat That Frog. Click here to watch "Eat That Frog!", which describes 21 ways to stop procrastinating and get more done in less time.

    • Download the Video Transcript
  • Lack of Organization

    Lack of organization is another common cause of procrastination. Organized people typically tend to have habits that help prevent procrastination like making a prioritized To-Do List. These are helpful because they can help determine how important the task is and identify precisely when it’s due. Prioritized lists often also identify how long a task will take to complete. You can avoid procrastination by breaking work down into manageable “next steps.”

  • Being Overwhelmed

    Even if you’re organized, you can feel overwhelmed by the task. You may doubt that you have the skills or resources you think you need, so you seek comfort in doing tasks you know you're capable of completing. Unfortunately, the big task isn't going to go away—truly important tasks rarely do!

What are two of your least favorite tasks that you tend to procrastinate? Place your response in the box below and then select the Submit button.

Step 3: Adopt Anti-Procrastination Strategies

Image by freepik under Freepik

If only it were as easy as just saying no to procrastination. There is a little more to it, but these tips & strategies can help.

Procrastination is a habit—a deeply ingrained pattern of behavior. That means you won’t just break it overnight. Habits only stop being habits when you have persistently stopped practicing them, so use as many approaches as possible to maximize your chances of beating them. Some tips will work better for some people than for others and for some tasks than others. Sometimes you may simply need to try a fresh approach to beat the “procrastination peril!”

These general tips will help motivate you to get moving:

  • Make up your own rewards. For example, promise yourself an ice-cream cone, or extra time spent with a favorite hobby once you've completed a certain task. Make note of how good it feels to finish things.
  • Ask someone else to check up on you. Peer pressure works! This is the principle behind many self-help groups and it is widely recognized as a highly effective approach.
  • Identify the unpleasant consequences of NOT doing the task.
  • Work out the cost of your time. Figure out how much money you may be losing in not getting things done in a timely manner. Hold yourself accountable for saving your business money by completing tasks on time.
  • Make it your goal to “eat the frog” first thing, every day!
